item.title: Thursday Night Pre-conference Drinks
item.description:
Thursday 15th, 20:00
Presenter: 
anthonylindsay

We'll meet in the Czech Inn on Thursday night from 8pm for pre-conf drinks. This is a great way to meet some old skool Drupal heads, and, if you are on your own coming to the conference, you won't be by the end of this night.
item.dc:creator: anthonylindsay

item.title: Registration
item.description:
Friday 16th, 9:15
Room: 
Reception Area

Event registration begins at 9:00am and will last until 9:30am.

Please arrive early to register and orietate yourself - you'll also get to meet other participants and speakers for a chat before the kick-off at 10:00am.
item.dc:creator: Mark Conroy

item.title: Hello and Welcome to Drupal Open Days
item.description:
Friday 16th, 9:45
Presenter: 
Mark Conroy

A very warm welcome to Drupal Open Days. Mark Conroy will kick-off proceedings.
item.dc:creator: Mark Conroy

item.title: Hello Drupal (Session 1)
item.description:
Friday 16th, 10:00
Presenter: 
heather
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
Drupal Development

We're holding same session three times, since there is limited space for each group. 

By the end of this short course, you will be able to...

  • Explain how a typical site is built in Drupal, and explain the page-model in Drupal.
  • Use Drupal specific terminology such as fields, views, node, block, page.
  • Understand how to build sites the "Drupal way"
  • How to use Drupal 7 which stable and mature
  • What's coming in Drupal 8 on the horizon
Online event registration for Hello Drupal - Session 1 - Dublin 2014 powered by Eventbrite
item.dc:creator: heather

item.title: Keynote: Live Free or Die Hard
item.description:
Friday 16th, 10:00
Presenter: 
jamessweeney
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
Business & Strategy

This years keynote will be given by Dr. Mihai Bilauca and James Sweeney. The talk will cover Limerick City and County Councils use of open source based technologies to remove vendor dependencies and deliver value to its users. In particular the talk will examine the Councils journey from proprietary content management systems to Drupal.
item.dc:creator: jamessweeney

item.title: A 3rd level institute's experience with using Drupal as a development platform
item.description:
Friday 16th, 11:00
Presenter: 
mgibbons
Session Level: 
Intermediate
Session Theme: 
General Web Development

GMIT's Martin Gibbons will give a presentation on how they have used Drupal to migrate some of their custom web sites, build new websites, and eventually have all web presences utilising Drupal's Open Source platform.

There will be time for Q&A at the end.

Slides
item.dc:creator: alanburke

item.title: The (Drupal) Project Life Cycle
item.description:
Friday 16th, 11:45
Presenter: 
emkay
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
General Web Development

The (Drupal) Project Life Cycle is a talk by project manager and agile scrum master Mike King.

The presentation goes through the life cycle of a web project, detailing what to expect from the developers, hosts, support, and client. In this presentation, Mike Covers the life cycle from project discovery, through the devlopment phase, acceptance testing to go live.

There will be time at the end for Q&A with Mike.

Slides: http://slides.com/emkay/drupal-project-lifecycle

Slides
item.dc:creator: emkay

item.title: Development of an Online Video Resource Library
item.description:
Friday 16th, 12:30
Presenter: 
Sile Ginnane
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
General Web Development

Overview of the development of an online video resource library as a mobile-first responsive website. Outline of challenges, development process and the sense that often an 'App' is not the best solution!
item.dc:creator: Sile Ginnane

item.title: Dublin Business Innovation Centre presentation
item.description:
Friday 16th, 14:00
Presenter: 
Mark Conroy
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
Business & Strategy

The Guinness Enterprise Centre is a dynamic community of high potential businesses. The centre is a hub of entrepreneurial enterprises and business and investment support services. The Guinness Enterprise Centre is located close to the Guinness Storehouse off Thomas Street, close to the Luas Line, Heuston Station and Motorway. Total floor area is 6,000 square metres with enterprise space for 70+ businesses, four conference rooms, café and reception. The centre is suitable to a wide range of businesses but in particular multi media, software development for mobile phone, computers, games, tourist and all international traded services. The centre offers a range of services these include high-spec telecommunications and internet connectivity, supported by wireless connection. The Guinness Enterprise Centre also offers a virtual office facility for companies that require an address without the expense of office space. Business support is available to all clients of the Guinness Enterprise Centre. In addition, clients are encouraged to participate in our extensive network of business and commercial events and contacts.

The centre has been a foundation for many businesses that have graduated and gone on to be highly successful.

  • 265 businesses have graduated through the Guinness Enterprise Centre
  • 17 Companies have expanded since graduating with sales of €70 million employing 474 with an equity investment of €46 million
  • 508 people are employed in the 77 companies that graduated through the centre
item.dc:creator: Mark Horgan

item.dc:creator: heather

item.title: You want to start a new web agency... but you're a developer
item.description:
Friday 16th, 14:05
Presenter: 
garyh
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
Business & Strategy

Setting up a company with your eyes wide open, boundless optimism and a clean slate is a transformative experience. If you haven't done this before and you come from a background that isn't business orientated means you can't possibly appreciate what is ahead of you. 

You can research, develop a roadmap and put a plan in place, but nothing is going to go as you thought. I don't believe you can learn how to do it but you need to learn to adapt and quickly rethink all of your assumptions.

You really will be winging it for a long time, you'll scramble, work insane hours, take on too much work and do far too many jobs yourself that get thrown at you from sales, development to filing(and paying) tax returns. Holidays? Forget those, if it's going to work you'll need to sacrafice some things in you personal life for a year or two.

If you did know what at least the next year of your life was going to look like after starting up, you may think twice before doing it, being niave and green is a good thing in that regard.

Carving out a niche and building a profile in a very competitve market is hard, but if it works out the rewards are worth it and you wouldn't change anything to get to where you did.

You need to accept you'll make a complete mess of some things but you'll do what it takes to make sure to never repeat those mistakes again. You need to never think that you've figured it all out and always be looking to improve every one of your processes.

This talk will give a bit of background on iterate and how we grew so quickly, we started in August 2011 and there are currently seven people working at iterate with two more joining the team at the start of June. 

We've moved from incubation offices to our own city centre location in Dublin. We're working on complex projects for large organisations, redefining their online marketing strategy and overhauling and improving existing internal processes, resulting in significant cost savings.

This talk will hopefully be useful to anyone who is currently running a service based company or is thinking of doing so. I'll discuss the processes, staff and structures we put in place that saw us scale quickly in the last year.

Slides
item.dc:creator: garyh

item.title: Drupal Open Q&A
item.description:
Friday 16th, 15:00
Presenter: 
Mark Conroy
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
General Web Development

This is an open table discussion about Drupal, with a panel of the best of Ireland's Drupal talent. Basically, if you:

  • are wondering about adopting Drupal, but haven't made up your mind;
  • have a Drupal website, but have some issues with it;
  • are weighing up the pros and cons of open source versus proprietary software;
  • are concerned about the Drupal "learning cliff";
  • are investigating hosting solutions for Drupal;

then, come along, pitch your question, and get some answers.
item.dc:creator: Mark Conroy

item.title: Social Media Tips & Tricks for Business
item.description:
Friday 16th, 15:45
Presenter: 
Tim.ODriscoll
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
Business & Strategy

This course will describe the role that some of the major internet companies like Google (Analytics), Facebook (Business pages) & Twitter are playing into today’s society and how they can benefit you as an individual or small business. 
The session is ideally suited for those who want to calculate the ROI of Social media, understand what function the Website should play & its Goals. It will also show you how your can build Brand awareness & picking the Social media platform is right for you.

Overview 

  • Website & its Goals
  • Your Brand
  • What Social media platform is right for you?
  • The Platforms (Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Pinterest & Flickr)
  • The Tools (Tracking & Benchmarking)
  • Reviewing & Improve

 

Slides
item.dc:creator: Tim.ODriscoll

item.title: Friday Night Social
item.description:
Friday 16th, 16:30
Presenter: 
anthonylindsay

We've got an area reserved at JW Sweetmans for the Friday night. Platters for 10 cost €35 - we'll be having some of those. There'll be questions (with a difference) and prizes (to die for). A great night, guaranteed.
item.dc:creator: anthonylindsay

item.title: Creating the "Wow Factor" with Drupal
item.description:
Saturday 17th, 10:00
Presenter: 
anthonylindsay
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
Drupal Development
  • You've got a brief
  • You're ready to develop
  • You fulfill the clients needs
  • Then ... you go that one step further and create "The Wow Factor"
Slides
item.dc:creator: anthonylindsay

item.title: Drupal DevOps
item.description:
Saturday 17th, 10:30
Presenter: 
geewiz
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
Drupal Development

The age of projects where everyone works in their own silo without knowing of the contributors around them is coming to an end. Agile methodologies break up departmental borders and merge specialists to an end-to-end team.

In my talk, I'm going to highlight best practices how we can get rid of the dreaded "wall of confusion" between developers and sysadmins in order to collaborate more effectively within Drupal projects.

Slides
item.dc:creator: geewiz

item.title: Using research to avoid creating crimes against humanity
item.description:
Saturday 17th, 11:00
Presenter: 
karen.iterate
Session Level: 
Intermediate
Session Theme: 
Business & Strategy

Web design projects usually start off great – excitement and enthusiasm all round. Your client has hired you to create a great new website and that’s exactly what you’re going to do. But amid all the excitement and enthusiastic handshakes, you forget one crucial thing; your client has no idea what they want.

By adopting an in-depth research phase into your projects, you can avoid creating crimes against humanity (in web form).

This is a lesson in knowing how and when to say no.

Slides
item.dc:creator: karen.iterate

item.title: Coffee Break
item.description:
Saturday 17th, 11:30

We all need a little break sometimes.
item.dc:creator: Mark Conroy

item.title: Automated Testing
item.description:
Saturday 17th, 11:45
Presenter: 
gavinhughes
Session Level: 
Intermediate
Session Theme: 
General Web Development

Ever had a problem where a new piece of functionality has broken another part of your site and you didn't know about it in time? We all know we need to test before we deploy, and in this in this session I will explore how you can prevent such problems and why that will help you sleep better!
item.dc:creator: gavinhughes

item.title: Multilingual in Drupal 8, and differences with Drupal 7
item.description:
Saturday 17th, 12:15
Presenter: 
luisrc7
Session Level: 
Advanced
Session Theme: 
Drupal Development

In this session you will get an overview of how multilingual works in Drupal 8, how to configure it and how to get a fully working multilingual website in only a few simple steps.

I will cover the differences between drupal 7 multilingual and the new multilingual in Drupal 8 and how in Drupal 8 is much more easy to achieve a satisfactory result.

Slides
item.dc:creator: luisrc7

item.title: Saving Time with Solr Searches
item.description:
Saturday 17th, 13:45
Presenter: 
TLyngeJ
Session Level: 
Intermediate
Session Theme: 
General Web Development

A brief review of Solr and how to use it as an alternative to the Drupal Core Search module.

The session will cover:

  • Basic intro to what Solr is
  • How to set it up, very briefly
  • A demo of more complex features
  • The gain by using Solr, time saved per search.
Slides
item.dc:creator: TLyngeJ
